question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: our design connected to quite a few of the earth's systems such as: the hydrosphere by including a water purifier that would make rainwater our drinking water. the biosphere by giving animals little habitats such as ponds, bug hotels, the green roofs and bushes the geosphere by using our food waste as compost to help our soil
feedback: Fantastic response linking to different systems of the world such as hysosphere but also making the links to a local design level.  Student also mentioned more than one system and then started to explain links.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: The main benefit to communities if all schools used food waste as compost would be healthy soil that would be easier to grow vegetables in, therefore costing less and more environmently friendly because the trucks that deliver the vegetables would not produce as much greenhouse gasses
feedback: Fantastic work looking at composting and linkd to less carbon emissions.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our main project was the carbon monitor. The carbon monitor monitored the carbon levels in the room and when it went to high the windows automatically opened which then the classroom was filled with fresh air. This design had many design features as we focused on how we can make the air quality better in the classroom which comes under The Earth's Atmosphere. Our design feature also included building materials for the monitor itself and the windows. Also its biodiversity features which we used as a biophilic design for the windows and a biodegradable plastic for the carbon monitor. In the project we thought a lot about how we can make our design more Eco- friendly which took a lot of consideration and thinking when thinking for designs. Our design will have such a positive impact on the planet. We focused on how we can help the planet and not how we can make it better. This is because we need to help the planet in steps and do little things which have a great outcome. Like how we can make the air quality in the classroom better which allows major health benefits for young people as with fresh air it increases focus,happy moods and a more positive way to look at learning.
feedback: This is an emplorary answer.  The learner looks at a range of environmental issues and clearly responds and identifies different systems.  Linking the positivity of varoius systems to health benefits.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: In Port Talbot we are most famous for our steel works which pollutes lots of harmful gases. In Port Talbot it is quite common for children to have asthma as children breathe in unhealthy air. Our project will make the air better in classrooms but also the community breathing in better air. This feature will help schools adapt to breath healthy and clean air which increases more happy moods in the community which leads to less trouble.
feedback: Very high order response that looks at impact on local community.  Also liks to reduction in greenhousegaseswhich shows a wider understanding

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our main subject was creating a carbon monitor connected to the classroom windows, so when there isn't enough air, the windows open automatically. That allows more air in the classroom, and no wasted time getting up to close the window. Also, the window frame would be made from aluminium which is sustainable. We also had chairs made out of the uniform from the year 6 leavers to stop wasting clothes that could be used for something entirely different. The uniform would also make the chairs comfy and match the colour of the school.
feedback: This learner identifies the issues associated with their design and explains the main component marks well.  However they fail to fully explain the link on the follow up answer.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: If all schools in Wales installed carbon monitors which automatically open windows, kids would be breathing fresher air and it could also prevent kids getting sick more often. This would also reduce the need for energy-intensive ventilation systems.
feedback: Shows the linking of carbon to climate change and how reducing benefits local as in people and global as in climate change.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: My features mostly connect with sustainable and sustainably sourced materials. Because i used sustainable materials, it means that i am not destroying the wildlife in the area. This also allows bugs and insects to live by the materials and can use them for their own good.
feedback: Learner identifies how they are linking their design to a system and uses key phrases like sustaianble.  However learner fails to fully explain this  point and benefit on a larger scale.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: If all schools in wales used my feature in their designs, it would be alot more sustainable in the long run. I think that it would help the environment alot.
feedback: Eludes to sustainaility but fails to fully explain.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: We tried to include things to help the enviroment and biophilic design
feedback: learner uses word biophillic but fails to fully explain and justify the linknto the environment and future development.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: We could reduce plastic waste by reusing it for things
feedback: Shows basic understading of recycling

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our design was more of a biosphere, where we created things using old materials while also making it bug and animal friendly, e.g. we had a bug hotel wall,and a massive hedge to both serve as a home and a wall. We also helped the atmosphere by having solar panels creating energy for the kitchen and therefore having less carbon emissions.
feedback: Learner explains their design and link to biophillic but fails to fully explain how else they can link to the biosphere, or any other system.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: I think if all schools in Wales used my feature, the schools would end up being both environmentally friendly and a fun place for children to play. Plus my design would help schools both a) pay less in the summers for electricity and b) potentially get more money, as I know that the Government will pay you for the electricity you make and end up not using.
feedback: Fantastic answer making clear links between environment and energy use and sustainabilty

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: i think we can use water energy to get us more renewable stuff for schools and just places around the world

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: if all schools in Wales thought about their input about stuff with solar panels or windmills they could get a good input whilst the company they get the energy from has a good input too they might get more input then output
feedback: starts to talk about enegy resiliance which is good.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Biodiversity Features,we had thought of using the tides from the beach as a way of energy and using bamboo and making a bug hotel
feedback: learner starts to make some interesting links and seems to start looking at systems but never quite getting there.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: it will have a renewable energy and less harm in the world
feedback: looks at renewable energy and link to Co2, basic understanding shown on the concepts.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: I think if all schools used my chosen feature then it would be more sustainable because the schools are made out of wood and we can re-grow trees. I think that if we add fruits and more water fountains then the school would be more healthy too. If we use the motion detected lights then we would save money for the school to buy more other things.
feedback: Links really well between the idea of where outr materials come from on a global scale to benefits on a local scale.  Also linking lights and energy use to global warming.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: in our group we produced a 3d model crafted from household receycled material, based on the outside yard social spaces. To include nature in our design we implanted huge 18ft hedges surrounding the pertimiter of the school. this idea will make kids feel positive when the stunning greenary catches their eyes. these hedges will also make children feel normal not like their trapped in a cage like the effect boring metal fences give out
feedback: Fantastic further explanation linking to the benfit to the atmosphere made from the planting of hedges.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

feedback: Some sustainable aspects talked about here but never really linking to the design feature.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our design was for the outdoor area for the children to play. We took into consideration the biosphere, we connected plants to the area for the wildlife and animals to connect with the area.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: I think that the pollution levels would be a lot less and more children would grow up with experience outdoors so they would know how to make a difference when they get to adulthood.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: We did a vegetable patch with a compost bin so any leftover food from the canteen can go into there for animals to eat. I think this connects with biosphere because it's for the animals and plants. I think this helps the environment by feeding the animals and getting rid of the food in an environment friendly way.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

- Atmosphere connects with our project the most
- Our idea was to let in fresh air through the window it there's too much carbon dioxide detected in the classroom
- It lets people breath better, concentrate/focus.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer:
Earth's Natural Systems include:
Hydrosphere - all water on Earth (oceans, lakes, rivers, groundwater, rain)
Atmosphere - the air around our planet (weather, climate, air quality)
Biosphere - all living things and where they live (plants, animals, habitats)
Geosphere - the solid parts of Earth (soil, rocks, mountains)
feedback: again repeating the question with No thought of the actual processes.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: t, Energy Systems,
feedback: Discusses energy that shows a small link that the pupil needs to develop futher.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.

We would have lots of windows for natural sunlight as well as sky lights and renewable energies to power lights and our ovens. We had a green roof and some solar panels. We had a plant area to chill and our benches and other stuff were made with sustainable wood.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
